The patient is a 39-year-old female who presented from Hospital1 with seizures, right upper lobe (RUL) infiltrate, and respiratory distress. She has a history of preeclampsia with severe features (PIH) and was 3 weeks postpartum at the time of presentation. 

The patient's current medications include levofloxacin, famotidine, and heparin. She has been treated with clindamycin and ceftriaxone for MSSA infection. Her blood pressure is being managed with labetalol and nifedipine to maintain a goal of less than 160/90 mmHg. 

The patient has an ongoing urinary tract infection (UTI) due to Klebsiella, which is covered by levofloxacin and will be treated for a total of 7 days. She also has a history of posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) associated with eclampsia. 

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C (98.7°F), heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure of 136/74 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. She is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. Her ABG results show a pH of 7.40, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 345 mmHg, and respiratory system compliance of 50 cmH2O/mL. 

The patient's physical examination reveals that she is well-nourished, overweight/obese, and in no acute distress. Her cardiovascular examination is normal, and her peripheral pulses are present and equal bilaterally. Her respiratory/chest examination shows symmetric expansion and clear breath sounds without wheezes. 

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 9.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 11.5 g/dL, platelet count of 293 K/uL, sodium level of 135 mg/dL, potassium level of 4.5 mEq/L, glucose level of 82 mg/dL, and C-reactive protein (CRP) level of 28 mg/dL. Blood cultures grew MSSA, and her urine culture grew Klebsiella. 

The patient's plan includes continuing levofloxacin, providing ventilator precautions, and attempting extubation today. Her blood pressure will be managed with labetalol and nifedipine, and she will be monitored for hypertension and eclampsia. She will also be consulted with neurology regarding PRES and will continue to treat hypertension. Additionally, she will be treated for urinary tract infection, and her feeds will be held with a plan of extubation tomorrow.
